keyTakeAways: Walmart has paused job offers to foreign applicants requiring H-1B visas following President Donald Trump's announcement of a $100,000 fee on H-1B visas.
The H-1B visa program is crucial for U.S. companies to hire skilled foreign workers, especially in tech and e-commerce sectors.
Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the U.S., currently employs over 2,000 H-1B visa holders, making it a major player in the program.

The new visa fee is intended to curb perceived abuse of the H-1B program but may disproportionately affect skilled professionals from India, who have historically made up the majority of H-1B applicants.

This policy shift demonstrates how corporate hiring practices are adapting to changes in U.S. immigration policy and could have broad implications for high-skilled foreign talent in American businesses.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Walmart, the largest private-sector employer in the United States, has paused job offers to foreign applicants requiring H-1B visas in response to President Donald Trump’s announcement of a $100,000 fee on the program. This policy shift reflects growing concern among companies over rising costs and accessibility issues related to hiring skilled foreign talent, particularly from India, who have historically dominated H-1B applications. While the Trump administration argues the fee is meant to curb abuse, economists and businesses warn it could hinder innovation and competitiveness, especially in high-growth sectors like e-commerce and technology. The move signals a broader realignment of corporate hiring strategies under tighter immigration regulations.
title: Walmart halts job offers for applicants who need H-1B visas after Trump raises fees to $100,000
